title: Effect of a Mitosis Disrupting Chemical

content.description:
Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.

Many types of cancer are treated with a combination of therapies. In lung cancer, some tumors respond well to the drug paclitaxel followed by radiation treatment. Paclitaxel is a chemical that disrupts mitosis. Instead of spindle fibers originating from the two sides (poles) of the cell, paclitaxel-treated cells develop three poles and then divide into three cells (tripolar division). Radiation therapy is more effective on tumor cells that have undergone tripolar division than on cells that have undergone normal mitosis.

Researchers treated cancer cells in the lab with different concentrations of paclitaxel for <math alttext="15" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>15</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> hours. The researchers then determined the average percent of mitotic cells that were tripolar. The results are shown in Table 1.

TABLE 1. EFFECT OF PACLITAXEL CONCENTRATION ON PERCENT OF MITOTIC CELLS THAT WERE TRIPOLAR

Concentration of Paclitaxel (<math alttext="nanomolar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>nM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>)

Average Percent of Mitotic Cells that were Tripolar

(<math alttext="plus or minus 2 S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>)

<math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.0 plus or minus 0.0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mo>±</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mn>0.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="17.0 plus or minus 3.0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>17.0</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mo>±</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mn>3.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="48.0 plus or minus 3.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>48.0</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mo>±</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mn>3.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="65.0 plus or minus 5.0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>65.0</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mo>±</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mn>5.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="70.0 plus or minus 4.0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>70.0</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mo>±</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mn>4.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="50.0 plus or minus 2.0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.0</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mo>±</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mn>2.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

The <math alttext="A U R K A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">AURKA</mtext></mrow></math> gene encodes an enzyme that helps assemble the spindle fibers, which signals the cells to continue through mitosis. When researchers analyzed the levels of <math alttext="A U R K A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AURKA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein in different types of cancer cells, they found that cancer cells expressing high levels of <math alttext="A U R K A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AURKA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein had more tripolar divisions when treated with paclitaxel, than did cancer cells expressing low levels of <math alttext="A U R K A" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mtext>AURKA</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> protein.
content.question: (a) Describe the situations in which a normal human cell would enter the cell cycle and undergo mitotic cell division. Explain how spindle fibers help ensure the products of mitosis are two identical cells with a full set of chromosomes.

frqParts.text: (a) Describe the situations in which a normal human cell would enter the cell cycle and undergo mitotic cell division. Explain how spindle fibers help ensure the products of mitosis are two identical cells with a full set of chromosomes.

(b) Using the template in the space provided for your response, construct an appropriately labeled graph that represents the data shown in Table 1. Based on the data, determine the concentration(s) of paclitaxel that is (are) most effective in causing tripolar cell division.

(c) Based on the data, identify the lowest level of paclitaxel that will allow for at least <math alttext="50%" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> of the cells to be tripolar. From the start codon through the stop codon, the length of the fully processed <math alttext="A U R K A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AURKA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="1,212" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext>,212</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> nucleotides. Calculate the number of amino acids in the polypeptide chain coded for by the <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Predict the effect of a mutation that prevents the expression of <math alttext="A U R K A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AURKA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> on a normal (noncancerous) cell.
